body:
You can configure the technologies associated with a context via the 'context' component, and then specify that context when starting the active scan.
Hopefully that will meet your requirements?

I looked through the code base to determine where the technologies are pulled from the Context and passed to the ActiveScanController. It appears that this only happens when a user is specified. See https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy/blob/develop/src/org/zaproxy/zap/extension/ascan/ActiveScanAPI.java#L542

rename.from: Allow configuration of scan policy technology via REST API
rename.to: Technologies are not set from Context when scanning via REST API

body: We need to fix that then - you should definitely be able to scan a context without specifying a user.
I put together a patch that merges contexts then sets them manually. It's referenced from this ticket and I'll send a pull request.

issue.title: Set technologies based on URL contexts

repository.name: zaproxy
repository.description: The ZAP by Checkmarx Core project

issue.body:
Retrieve contexts in which the specfied
URL is included, then merge their tech-
nology lists and pass them to the scan
controller.

Addresses zaproxy/zaproxy#1853

body:
I've to disagree with assessment of the issue, the problem is not that the technologies are not set, the problem is that it's not possible to specify a context (which has its technologies).
I think the API should be changed to specify a context not to set the technologies of the contexts, it will be more consistent with the functionalities provided in GUI.
Not saying that the API should not allow to specify the technologies used in the scan (it should be possible like it is in GUI with "Technology" tab in "Active Scan" dialogue).

The API already allows for the specification of a context -- multiple contexts, in fact -- via the combination of importContext and setContextInScope. Were the API to be modified in the way that you indicate, there would still need to be code changes to respect the context-selected technologies at scan time. This is the reason for the referenced patch merging TechSet's. A given target may appear in scope in multiple contexts.

And I concur that it would be reasonable and intuitive to have the API function similarly to the active scan GUI. In such case, I think that the API should respect the technology selections in both the context and active scan configuration.

Sorry for not being clear, I was talking about the active scan API, not the ZAP API as whole.
The active scanner already uses the technologies of the specified context, no other changes would be required other than change active scan API to allow to specify the context.

Regarding the target appearing in multiple contexts, well it's possible but I wonder how would that work in practice (i.e. authentication, authorisation, structural parameters). As said in the review of the pull request, in other cases where a context is selected for a given target it's just used the first one.

My read of the code indicates that the active scanner does not already use the technologies specified in the context. That is the reason for this bug and accompanying patch. I observed that selected technologies are only respected when scanning as a specific user. When not scanning as a specific user, no technologies are used. This was corroborated by code review as well as observation of generated traffic at runtime. Are you saying that this observation is incorrect?

What I'm saying is that it's not possible (and should be) to specify a context (therefore it's technologies) through the active scan API.
The active scanner does use the technologies of the specified context. [1]

[1] https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy/blob/8e7a8ed4ad897ba481379e6c283ef87bc2a5ee08/src/org/zaproxy/zap/extension/ascan/ActiveScanController.java#L153

issue.title: Active Scan API - scan the whole context

repository.name: zaproxy
repository.description: The ZAP by Checkmarx Core project

issue.body:
Currently the ascan API provides these two methods:

```
scan (url* recurse inScopeOnly scanPolicyName method postData )
scanAsUser (url* contextId* userId* recurse scanPolicyName method postData ) 
```

both of them require the URL parameter. However, I would like to run the ascan in a similar way I run the spider - using my whole context (without having to specify a url): `zap.spider.scan_as_user(ctx_id, user_id)`

rename.from: Technologies are not set from Context when scanning via REST API
rename.to: Allow to active scan a Context through ZAP API

body: Updated the issue to allow to specify a context when starting the active scan through the ZAP API (per comments in #1855).
Merged #2722 into this issue, as pointed out, the URL should not be required when a context is specified (as proposed in this issue and when active scanning as a user).

issue.title: Allow to active scan a Context through the ZAP API

repository.name: zaproxy
repository.description: The ZAP by Checkmarx Core project

issue.body:
Change ActiveScanAPI to:
 - Allow to specify a context for the "scan" action;
 - Not require the URL, in the actions "scan" and "scanAsUser", if
 the context is specified (for the latter action it is always).

Add helper method to ApiImplementor that validates that an API parameter
exists.

Fix #1853 - Allow to active scan a Context through ZAP API

issue.title: Active Scan API - Scan whole context as user incorrectly requires a URL

milestone.description: Enhancements and bug fixes expected to be included in a following main release.

repository.name: zaproxy
repository.description: The ZAP by Checkmarx Core project

issue.body:
As explained in #2722 and #1853, it was not possible to start an active scan in a context via the API without specifying an URL. This issue clearly seems to be fixed, since the following API call starts an active scan in my preferred context:
http://localhost:8080/JSON/ascan/action/scan?apikey=****&recurse=true&contextId=1

Using the equivalent API call for scanAsUser (with HTTP/NTLM authentication)
http://localhost:8080/JSON/ascan/action/scanAsUser?apikey=****&recurse=true&contextId=1&userId=11
results in the API output `{"code":"internal_error","message":"Internal Error"}` and zap.log file with the following content:
```
net.sf.json.JSONException: JSONObject["url"] not found.
	at net.sf.json.JSONObject.getString(JSONObject.java:2092)
	at org.zaproxy.zap.extension.ascan.ActiveScanAPI.handleApiAction(ActiveScanAPI.java:249)
	at org.zaproxy.zap.extension.api.API.handleApiRequest(API.java:431)
	at org.parosproxy.paros.core.proxy.ProxyThread.processHttp(ProxyThread.java:456)
	at org.parosproxy.paros.core.proxy.ProxyThread.run(ProxyThread.java:317)
	at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:748)
```

However adding the parameter "url" with a valid URL as value works as expected - starting an active scan in my preferred context using my specified HTTP authentication user credentials.

I guess the problem (#2722) has only been fixed for non-authenticated scans.

I would like the scan to behave exactly as when starting it via the GUI and selecting a context as "starting point". When using no authentication (or using the spider) this can be done by not specifying the "url" parameter.

body: This thread has been automatically locked since there has not been any recent activity after it was closed. Please open a new issue for related bugs.
